title: Japanese mascot belts out Welsh national anthem arm in arm with players
text:
The mascot was understandably dwarfed by 6ft 6ins tall Alun Wyn Jones (Picture: PA)

Wales’ national anthem is one of rugby’s great spectacles and it didn’t disappoint before their big quarter final today.

The sound of tens of thousands of passionate Welsh men and women singing their hearts out in their native tongue is up there with New Zealand’s famous pre-match haka.

And few sing ‘Hen Wlad Fy Nhadau’ (Land of My Fathers) with as much pride as Wales captain Alun Wyn Jones.

But he had a little help today, in the shape of a comparatively tiny Japanese boy.

The tournament mascot showed Wales every respect by learning the words to the iconic anthem and duly belting them out.

It seems he was a good luck charm as well, with Wales coming from behind to narrowly beat France 20-19 at the Oita Stadium.

The mascot sings with the Wales players ahead of the quarter-final match (Picture: AP)

The sight of the young mascot singing arm in arm with all 6ft 6ins of the Welsh captain was adored by viewers watching at home.

TV presenter Nick Knowles tweeted: ‘The young Japanese Welsh mascot must have learned Welsh National anthem as sang it all through.

‘How amazing is that!!’

Gillian Jeffery wrote: ‘I’m sure I just saw the Japanese lad who is stood with the Welsh team singing their national anthem.

‘If he was then what an amazing young man.’

But Wales were not the only country showed this honour during the World Cup.

The Japanese hosts have made sure every mascot learns the words to each national anthem before every game.

Wales’ mascot for the Fiji game only came up to Wyn Jones’ belly button, but he gave it everything, and even put his hand on his heart while doing it.

Passionate mascot sings the Welsh national anthem before the Fiji game (Picture: Shaun Botterill/Getty)
